bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ralph Shapiro joined the National Lawyers Guild (NLG) after World War II. The NLG was founded in 1937 as an association of progressive lawyers and jurists who believed that lawyers had a major role to play in reconstructing legal values by emphasizing human rights over property rights. The Guild is the oldest and most extensive network of public interest and human rights activists working within the legal system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains papers from Shapiro's years in the NLG which address issues such as racial discrimination on television and legal representation for civil rights demonstrators in the South during the 1960s. The collection also contains NLG reports on various social issues, with emphasis on health care coverage.
